column44: Although at times I do feel burnt out, I truly know that I have one of the greatest jobs in the world in which I am able to support students and families each day. I have not searched for mental health services, but there are days when I think other career choices would have been an easier way to go. Despite challenging days, weeks, or even some years in the field I am confident that I chose the right career path for me.
column45: Although I have not worked in a medical setting, I completed an externship in a hospital during grad school. In that setting I liked feeling like I had more time dedicated to paperwork as needed (SOAP notes, etc.) However, in the school setting I find that there are many resources to support mental health that I did not have access to in the hospital.

column44: No
Yes, I did seek out resources for my mental health.
column46: Lack of training in each setting

column44: No but it did prompt me to take an almost 2 week vacation and I have cut back on a bunch of voluntary work projects and cut back on working from home
column46: Side projects away from direct patient care such as supervising graduate practicum students, mentoring an undergraduate student, presenting a couple of CEUs to my staff, receiving an Asha grant to start a new program and preparing for our convention presentation, serving on practice teams, etc have led me to realize I’m doing way too much and working 4 10-hour days significantly cuts into my personal time. I’m trying to find a better balance so that my entire life doesn’t revolve around speech pathology.

column44: Yes. No other jobs taken though.
column46: So much less money per hour than physical therapy. Other professionals making more per hour than us.

column44: I spend about 1-2 looking at current job postings, but do not apply
column46: Pay

column44: Yes, I got very burned out after 10yrs at a SPED school and so I switched to my current regular ed school. What burned me out was dealing with a terrible administrator. For three years at my current school I adored my administrator and felt no stress, despite covid. However, this year I have a new administrator who is really stressful so far and I’m contemplating leaving because of her. My work doesn’t stress me out, but my boss somehow does have the power to stress me out.

Yes, mental health services helped me to decide to decrease my hours per week at work in October 2020. I have maintained those hours which has helped my stress levels. The downside is less pay but happiness is more important than money.
column46: I work at a school and often feel a lack of support from my special education department. My boss is the director of special education and she has no time to meet with my directly. I am mostly a free agent doing whatever I want at work. This has many pros and cons, the cons being when workload gets too high there is no one who seems to care to support me. Concerns often seem to fall on deaf ears if I can even find a time for anyone to meet with me. The special education department has a lot of turnover which means that new employees need much more support than seasoned ones and I’m expected to just keep doing what I’m doing even if there are many workload issues that lead to me not being able to provide the best services for my students.

column44: I’’m not burned out yet, mostly because I have a unionized workplace.I used to work in non-union environments, private schools, charter schools, and our labor was excessively exploited. My union collectively bargains for our wages and working conditions, and so now, as of 2014, I get to take a duty-free, 50-minute lunch break, a 45-minute Prep period, and 45-min Admin period, for SESIS documentation, assessments and writing IEPs. The union makes all the difference. It’s a question that should be included in the survey: union or non-union workplace? It makes a world of difference in quality of life on the job. UFT also provides us with PTO, we only work 180 days a year, which is not the case for private school SLPs, and contracted fee-for-service SLPs. Mental health with a Union to back us up is much more high quality.
column45: Our Union (UFT) offers free mental health counseling through UFT MAP. Non union union workplaces did not offer that. On the contrary, they drove us crazy, to the point of quitting.
column46: I (previously), not now, had an abusive administrator, in the NYCDOE, at a Bronx school. Despite us being unionized, bad administration is plentiful. Even if you’re the best SLP, most inspiring and most empathetic, most pro-active, if Admin doesn’t like you, they can still find ways to target you for termination. The UFT can help, but only so much. This can also be a factor in mental well-being: whether or not you have a good boss. This is a question that this survey should ask: “Do you have a good, fair boss?” It makes a big difference in mental health among SLPs.

column44: No

Yes. I sought out mental health counseling for anxiety and depression that was exacerbated by my job. I currently see a therapist every other week to address my anxiety and work is often a related aspect of that. My counseling seeks to help me see myself as human, that I will make mistakes, and that I have to have limits. However, these are not yet tools I feel I implement effectively. For others, I am compassionate, but not for myself. I hold myself to a high standard and that is the cycle of my anxiety.
column46: Other professionals who do not do their job and I have to patch it up. Other SLPs who have left compliance mistakes and issues I have to fix. Inequity of caseload distribution. Professionals who are not trained in basic classroom supports and I have to spend time documenting and training them.

column44: No
column45: NA
column46: Lack of ability to grow professionally and make financial gains.

column44: No

column46: reduced staff and ability to recruit qualified individuals to fill key positions

column44: In December 2021 I was offered a position outside of the field of speech therapy; I interviewed for the job and it felt exciting for the new opportunity after working non-stop in person during the pandemic. Ultimately did not take the position and happy I didn't now.
column45: Although still in a medical setting, changing companies recently has increased my mental health and has had a positive change to my outlook on day to day therapy.
column46: Feeling you are unable to help the client; or do not have the resources to help the client effectively, efficiently - the cost of good CEU courses

column44: It has never been burnout - it was having or making opportunities to advance and learn more; thus, the career change was to work with different clients; settings; opportunities to learn and expand my knowledge and skills;
column45: Working across settings - the one thing that helped me to feel supportive has been having a series of mentors. Also being involved as a volunteer in organizations helped to put things in perspective; Above all, being intentional about work-life balance helped me to maintain mental health;
column46: Lack of administrative support or understanding of the role and responsibilities of a SLP has impacted job satisfaction; also lack of parent support was a factor; having colleagues that were not contributors or motivated to "do the work" is a factor in work-related stress (e.g. fell on the worker bees to carry the load)

column44: None - have not reached threshold for requiring outside support
column45: The more the environment is like a "business" the less care regarding mental health I've noticed with higher adminstrators
column46: Workload vs. caseload based on behavioral/dx severity

column44: No
column45: Most of my career has been in the Practice Practice setting in which I feel being surrounded by other SLPs has been a huge benefit to mental health.
column46: The support of other medical providers to allow for a multidisciplinary approach.

column44: n/a
column45: Medical setting treat you more like robots, they care more about meeting the therapy cap than their workers. School settings tend to overload their SLP's with high caseload numbers and not enough time to get everything done, let alone provide effective therapy every session, burnout is very common and its not hard to see why
column46: productivity standards, being overloaded with paperwork and deadlines with so many demands on one person.

column44: Would never switch Careers!! Love my job
column45: CF YEAR was probably the most difficult experience of my career. Finding a good therapist helped!! Now that I’m an SLP with C’s everything is much more relaxed and I love it
column46: CF year I was taking home 20 hrs of work a week. It was miserable, but it’s worth it to keep pushing because now I only work in office and go home and have a separate and more relaxed life

column44: I am currently working in a private practice for the past year and before this I was in a school for 9 years. The burnout of a school made me switch populations. Being in a school is very draining for your mental health.
column45: The school that I worked in had mental health professional developments as well as days that we got out of work early for self-care. My current position in the private practice is a part-time position and there is no stress on self-care of mental health.
I feel that slps are rarely given thought. We aren’t treated the same in the building. I feel that teachers are given more materials to use.
column46: Behavior my students are becoming much more demanding and emotional

column44: Not a career change, because in reality I do feel "stuck" at times.  I have to pay my bills. I have sought out therapy.
column46: Student absences on one hand causes relief for large caseload, but mostly, it makes it so hard to make progress that kids are staying on caseload longer. when they don't make progress (because of absences), it's not satisfying and makes me sad. The student population I work with is low income, struggling to afford to live in the area. A lot of kids coming into Kinder w/ no early intervention services, not enough quality language stimulation, that it can be sad/emotionally draining to be at work sometimes.

column44: N/A
column45: They offer services and support groups at my educational setting and it’s covered by insurance
column46: Lack of staff

column44: I have not sought out mental health services

I definitely considered completely changing the job I was in to a whole new profession. Teletherapy was horrible. However the amount of paper work/ paper trail that every step of the job requires is over the top.
column46: The lack of support from parents hinders progress and carryover/generalization. They just want you to fix the problem and not be an active participant in raising their child

column44: No
column45: My mental health has not been affected, thankfully.
column46: Management support.

column44: Yes, consider switching careers often after Covid
column45: Pressure to not take personal days ways on mental health. And when coming back after time off, completing make up sessions affect mental health
column46: Minimal time to prep for sessions and communicate with parents. Lack of support for taking personal days we are entitled to. Lack of support and time for make up sessions and still expected to do them.

column44: I have contemplated a career change in the past.
column45: I have learned you must have a good work life balance to succeed at your job.

column44: No
column46: My job has implemented Stress First Aid (SFA) to optimize colleagues mental health on a daily basis.

column44: Switching career contemplated for decades
column45: A broken system that just keeps piling on more and more, never taking anything away

column44: Yes; mental health services helped me decide to change work settings. Mental heath services helped me set boundaries, ask for help, and communicate my workload challenges with my administration. Then I was able to make a change after I knew the work setting was the issue. I knew that taking action now would increase my chances of staying in the field instead of applying for other types of jobs.
column45: I only have experience with one work setting.
column46: Being a minority SLP providing bilingual or trilingual services has impacted how I navigate a work setting. I am often called upon to assist on special cases and I am asked more questions than my counterparts. That on top of having a large caseload, facing racial violence/discrimination, and cultural differences in the workplace have a huge lasting impact on my mental health when it comes to my work.

column44: Yes. I want to leave the field and am currently trying to save up as much money before making the switxch.
column45: I find that both work settings can tax one's mental health. In the end, I learned to have better boundaries.
column46: too many responsibilities.

column44: Yes I have sought therapy and I am currently trying to leave clinics work and search for other careers in IT
column46: Physician distrust, Management, okie leadership, poor staffing, racism in healthcare, bias in healthcare, other disciplines stepping in SLP scope of practice,

column44: No
column46: Colleagues that do not follow regulations and do not provide evidence based practices.

column44: Yes, I considered a location/setting change but did not follow through due to worries about financial insecurity and mental health security related to moving to a place without family/friend support there.
column45: I have worked in both medical and educational settings in different facilities and my experiences have shown a commonality in speech-language pathology - productivity and patient retention matter more than the therapist providing the services, saying 'No' is implicitly frowned upon, setting boundaries is looked at as mutiny, and administration forgets their employees are human beings.
column46: Arbitrary rules, an increase in responsibility that was not equally reflected monetarily, a mindset of 'when I say 'jump,' you say 'how high?', and a lack of communication from management that comes across as reckless disregard. The company culture here lacks genuine support with no acknowlegement or resources of mental health issues related to being a healthcare worker, pre- and post-pandemic.

column44: no
column45: Make sure you seek proper support and don't hold onto things.

column44: Burnout in school setting caused me to seek new position in medical setting
column46: In school setting: lack of caseload cap

column44: Yes but services were not helpful. Have thought about getting into leadership to leave patient care.
column46: I am in leadership and have to still see patients. All I do is deal with team members complaints and their mental health and they never consider mine.

column44: Yes. I am receiving therapy biweekly and consider a career change but feel daunted by this task. I have also considered decreasing hours at my current job. However, this may not be an option financially.
column46: Pressure of “fixing” things, imposter syndrome, compassion fatigue, productivity standards.

column44: I began treatment for anxiety two years into the pandemic and sought out employer-provided healthcare services (though I didn't find them particularly helpful).  I have considered additional certifications for a career change but costs are prohibitive.  I currently receive job alerts from a local university.
Yes.  I have both applied for different jobs and looked into mental health services. I have not actually switched careers at this time.
column45: n/a
column46: In the hospital setting, we have to meet efficiency requirements as well as complete all of the other things that go along with being an SLP.

column44: no
column45: The school setting has attempted to put things in place to help overall mental health but my busy schedule does not allow me to access the services.
column46: Caseload numbers and large group sizes have an impact on the ability to provide effective therapy.

column44: No
column46: Difficult parents and paperwork

column44: One of the reasons i took on more leadership and mentorship in the field (e.g., Clinical Director, CF and SLPA Mentor, Lead SLP) was because I became very emotionally and physically drained, had a hard time 'leaving work at the door.' Adopting a parent coaching approach also helped alleviate this.
column45: When working in a SNF there was a lack of support given that patients sometimes died suddenly or were moved to other facilities without a Farewell. Therapists become close with their clients, so this aspect was particularly hard for me.
column46: As a whole, SLPs are underpaid, given our level of education, CEU requirements, and what other meeical providers receive. I believe this is partially due to being a female-dominant discipline.
Not enough time during the school day to complete necessary paperwork.  Too much emphasis by administration on caseload, rather than overall workload.

column44: Work stress related to having zero time to manage caseload responsibilities & plan/differentiate therapy for students with diverse speech-language needs during the school day, coupled with the responsibilities of daily life as a full-time working mother, and family loss/illness/tragedy leaves me feeling VERY overwhelmed.  Following the loss of my father, I found that I NEEDED to speak with someone about how overwhelmed I was feeling.  My job as an SLP in the schools doesn't leave much room for self-care.  At times, I suffer from burnout because I work as many hours outside of the school week as I do during the week.  Administrators only seem to care about our ability to provide direct service to students and do not acknowledge the legitimate need for SLPs to have time allotted in their school day to manage caseload responsibilities and plan lessons.
column46: As SLPs in the schools, we are paid according to the teachers' salary scale; however, SLPs often fall into many gray areas and are not treated equitably.  We don't get an extra 45 minute prep per week like classroom teachers do (for planning), our caseloads are not capped at 25, we are expected to complete Medicaid log notes on our own time; yet, we are expected to pay for CEUs to maintain our licensure.   The inequities are numerous.  Teachers are provided with substitute coverage so that they can test their students' reading levels.  We are provided with a 1 hour testing slot for re-evaluation testing per week.  This is not nearly enough time to test a student for his/her re-eval, so we often pull students during our lunch or prep.  Teachers routinely attend various trainings/meetings where they are away from their class.  We don't even have dept. meetings during the school day because we are not supposed to cancel students' sessions.  It's very frustrating to feel like we're the underdog and no one really cares about fairness and how it impacts our mental health.

column44: n/a
column45: n/a

column44: yes
column46: Hostile work environment and lack of concern/support from administration/HR

column44: no
Yes, I receive counseling

Yes, both. I considered a career change multiple times in the past several years. I took classes in the tech field, changed my resume and spoke with someone about transitioning from the medical field into the tech field. I also received mental health services shortly after working in-person through the first wave of Covid following severe, consistent panic attacks at work and at home which helped immensely.
column45: Mental health is not a concern of any administration in the health field I've worked for. It is wholly the employee's responsibility whether your work environment and burn-out contribute to it or not.
column46: Being forced to work through a global pandemic with no regard for my safety and well-being from my superiors, hostile work environment, productivity expectations, extensive paperwork expectations.

column45: Because of my students' increased anxiety levels, I am drawn into more meetings to address these concerns.

column44: Staff shortage and refusal to hire more
column46: Time: we need more time and less meetings, more time to call parents
